questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a laceration to the right forearm. The patient was jumping over a fence when he slipped and sustained a 3 cm laceration to his right volar forearm. Prior to repair of the laceration, a local anesthetic agent is injected around the edges of the wound. Next, the physician performs a test of sensation to determine readiness for repair. Which of the following best lists the order in which sensations are lost after administration of the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is provided with a peripheral nerve block with a local anesthetic for repair of a forearm laceration. Prior to repair of lacerations it is commonplace to check for adequate regional analgesia--usually by gently tapping the wound edges with a pin, or the sharp end of scissors. The order of sensation loss following administration of a local anesthetic is Pain>Temperature>Touch>Pressure.     

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers and myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.    

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pain>Temperature>Touch>Pressure :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Temperature>Touch>Pressure>Pain:
Incorrect: Pain is the first sensation to be lost after administration of local anesthetics, not the last.   
❌ Pressure>Touch>Pain>Temperature:
Incorrect: Pressure and touch are lost after pain and temperature, not before.   
❌ Pain>Pressure>Touch>Temperature:
Incorrect: Pain is the first sensation to be lost after administration of local anesthetics; however, pressure and touch are the last to be lost, not temperature.   
❌ Temperature> Pain >Touch>Pressure:
Incorrect: Pain is lost before temperature, not temperature before pain.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. An hour later, she gives birth to a stillborn infant. The patient states that she did not receive consistent prenatal care. An autopsy of the infant reveals cyclopia and cleft palate. Examination of the brain shows fused cerebral hemispheres. This condition was most likely caused by failure of differentiation of which of the following anatomical structures?
questions.solution:
Holoprosencephaly is a developmental anomaly of the embryonic forebrain (prosencephalon) and is commonly seen with other midline defects (e.g., cleft palate, cyclopia). There are three main types: alobar, semilobar, and lobar.  

  •  Alobar - the most severe, in which the brain fails to separate; it is accompanied by severe facial deformities (e.g. cyclopia). This condition is incompatible with life.  
  •  Semilobar - parietal division of the brain's hemispheres   
  •  Lobar - the least severe form, in which there is a considerable separation of the brain hemispheres  
Around the 3rd week of gestation, shortly after anterior neural tube closure, the three primary brain vesicles develop into the prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon. Up until the 5th week, these structures continue to develop into 5 secondary brain vesicles; the prosencephalon is divided into two hemispheres and differentiates into the telencephalon and diencephalon, while the rhombencephalon differentiates into the metencephalon and myelencephalon. Failure of the prosencephalon to divide into two hemispheres results in holoprosencephaly. On imaging, holoprosencephaly is characterized by fusion of the thalami and there is a single posteriorly located ventricle. While the exact pathogenesis is unknown, it has been linked to multiple genetic mutations (e.g, sonic hedgehog, zinc finger protein), chromosome abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and triploidy), and environmental factors (e.g., maternal diabetes, retinoic acid, and drug and alcohol abuse).      






Option Analysis

❌ Mesencephalon :
Incorrect: During embryonic development, the middle primary brain vesicle known as the mesencephalon (midbrain) will grow further but will not differentiate. The two major parts of the midbrain are the cerebral peduncles (anterior) and the corpora quadrigemina (superior & inferior colliculi [posterior]).   
❌ Rhombencephalon:
Incorrect: The rhombencephalon (or hindbrain) is the dorsal primary brain vesicle that gives rise to the metencephalon and myelencephalon. The metencephalon gives rise to the pons and cerebellum, while the myelencephalon develops into the medulla oblongata.   
✅ Prosencephalon:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myelencephalon:
Incorrect: The myelencephalon, which develops from the differentiation of the rhombencephalon (hindbrain), gives rise to the medulla, not the cerebral hemispheres.  
❌ Diencephalon:
Incorrect: The diencephalon develops from the prosencephalon (forebrain) into the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and eye cup. Holoprosencephaly is caused by the failure of the entire prosencephalon to differentiate, not just the diencephalon.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with worsening occipital headaches, gait disturbance, and diminished pain sensation. She recently burned herself while cooking after keeping her hand on a pan “that did not feel hot when touched.” The patient has also been experiencing worsening occipital headaches that wake her up from sleep as well as feelings of discoordination while walking. Vitals are within normal limits. Neurologic exam is notable for gait ataxia, down beating nystagmus, as well as bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. Which of the following anatomic structures is directly disrupted by this patient's disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient has worsening occipital headaches, ataxia, nystagmus, and bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. These findings are concerning for a Chiari I malformation with concomitant syringomyelia, which is likely compressing the anterior white commissure.    

Syringomyelia describes a cystic cavity within the spinal cord that is usually within the central canal. Most lesions are in the cervical spinal cord, but they can less commonly manifest in the thoracic or lumbar regions. These cystic malformations are associated with Chiari I malformation, which is characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that herniate below the level of the foramen magnum. Syringomyelia is also associated with spinal cord trauma, spinal tumors, and abscesses.    

Overtime, the syrinx can expand and compress the anterior white commissure, a structure directly anterior to the cervical canal. The anterior white commissure is the decussation site for the spinothalamic tracts, which relay pain and temperature sensation. As a result, syringomyelia causes a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities.  

Synringomelia is diagnosed with MRI and managed surgically via posterior fossa decompression or ventricular drainage, when clinically indicated. If untreated, the syringomyelia can cause permanent neurological disability, scoliosis, and neuropathic arthropathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Medulla:
Incorrect: The medulla is the site of decussation for the dorsal column pathway. It is rarely implicated in cases of syringomyelia, since these cystic cavities do not typically originate until the level of the cervical spine.  
❌  Cerebellar vermis :
Incorrect: The cerebellar vermis is herniated in individuals with Chiari II malformation. However, this patient has a “cape-like” loss of temperature and pain sensation in the upper extremities. These findings are likely due to a syrinx compressing the anterior white commissure, which contains fibers of the spinothalamic tract that relay pain and temperature sensation. 
✅ Anterior white commissure  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Anterior corticospinal tract :
Incorrect: This patient has a loss of temperature and pain sensation in the upper extremities that follows a “cape-like” distribution pattern. These findings are consistent with syringomyelia, which does not typically affect the anterior corticospinal tract. 
❌ Dorsal column pathway:
Incorrect: Patients with Chiari type I malformations may present with findings of diminished proprioception or ataxia. However, these symptoms are due to abnormalities with the cerebellum, rather than the effects of a syrinx compressing the dorsal column pathway.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician with worsening gait instability. Over the past few weeks, the patient has had several falls at school. Her mother has noticed that the patient’s gait appears uncoordinated and that she has occasionally been slurring her words. The patient’s physical exam is notable for high-arched feet, difficulty walking in a straight line, and decreased vibratory sensation in both the upper and lower extremities. She subsequently undergoes a genetic analysis, which demonstrates a GAA repeat on chromosome 9. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in individuals with this disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple features consistent with Friedreich ataxia, including pes cavus (high heel arch), gait ataxia, diminished vibratory sensation, and dysarthria. She has a genetic test demonstrating GAA repeats on chromosome 9, which is consistent with this diagnosis. The leading cause of mortality in patients with Friedreich ataxia is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  

Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat disorder due to GAA repeats on chromosome nine. These repeats result in limited expression of the frataxin gene, which encodes an iron binding protein that regulates iron chaperoning, detoxification, antioxidation, and mitochondrial iron storage in neurologic tissue, cardiac myocytes, and pancreatic tissue. Current theories postulate that limited frataxin causes mishandling of iron and subsequent impairment of mitochondrial functioning, leading to cellular injury and oxidative stress in the affected tissue.  

Clinically, Friedreich ataxia tends to present in late childhood or adolescence and is a slowly progressive disease. Patients typically have limb ataxia due to spinocerebellar tract degenration, spastic paralysis due to lateral cortiospinal tract degeneration, and decreased vibratory and proprioceptive sensation due to dorsal column degeneration. Additional clinical features include scoliosis, pes cavus, hammer toes, diabetes mellitus, and cardiac dysfunction.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Heart failure :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Respiratory failure :
Incorrect: Respiratory failure is a common cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with conditions such as Guillain-Barre syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and poliomyelitis. However, this patient’s combination of gait ataxia, high-arched feet, and sensory deficits is more concerning for Friedreich ataxia. The most common cause of death in individuals with this condition is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
❌ Subependymal giant cell tumors:
Incorrect: The most common cause of death in patients with tuberous sclerosis is thought to be progressive neurologic decline from subependymal tumors. However, this etiology is not the most common cause of death in patients with Friedreich ataxia.  
❌ Sepsis:
Incorrect: Many neurological diseases can lead to difficulty protecting the airway, aspiration pneumonia, and subsequent sepsis. However, this patient’s combination of gait ataxia, high-arched feet, and sensory deficits is concerning for Friedreich ataxia. The most common cause of death in individuals with this condition is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, as opposed to sepsis. 
❌ Hypercoagulable state  :
Incorrect: A hypercoagulable state can be present in patients with underlying malignancies or thrombotic disorders. Hypercoagulability can predispose patients to developing pulmonary emboli. While patients with Friedreich ataxia are more prone to a hypercoagulable state due to immobility, it is not the leading cause of mortality.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 20 weeks gestation is being evaluated for abnormal ultrasound results several days ago. A single amniotic sac was visualized and the amniotic fluid index during that time was 25 cm (normal 8-18). The pregnancy has been uncomplicated so far, and the patient has been consistent with prenatal care and taking prenatal vitamins. Medical history is notable for asthma, managed with albuterol as needed. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, and uterine size is large for gestational date. An amniocentesis is performed and reveals elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with polyhydramnios and elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), suggesting the diagnosis of anencephaly. Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of significant portions of the brain and calvaria of the fetus, which results in elevated levels of amniotic fluid (polyhydramnios) due to decreased swallowing ability.  

Open neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital anomalies that develop when the neural tube fails to close normally during the third and fourth weeks of gestation. NTDs may be open (e.g., myelomeningocele, meningocele, encephalocele, and anencephaly) or closed (e.g., spina bifida occulta). Anencephaly occurs when the rostral neuropore fails to close, resulting in an absent calvarium and forebrain. Open NTDs result in a persistent connection between the amniotic cavity and spinal canal, and therefore AFP and acetylcholinesterase are often elevated. Screening is done via either ultrasound, demonstrating the absence of brain and calvaria, or AFP level measurement. In contrast, closed neural tube defects (e.g. spina bifida occulta) do not result in an elevated AFP level.  

Risk factors for developing closed or open neural tube defects include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine).  



Option Analysis

❌ Twin pregnancy:
Incorrect: Although twin pregnancies are associated with elevated AFP, polyhydramnios is not typically seen. In monochorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancies, polyhydramnios is associated with twin-twin transfusion syndrome; this syndrome would manifest as oligohydramnios in one amniotic sac and polyhydramnios in the other sac. However, only one amniotic sac was visualized here, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Spina bifida occulta:
Incorrect: Spina bifida occulta, also known as closed neural tube defect, is a bony defect in which the posterior vertebral arches fail to fuse, with unexposed neural tissue and intact overlying skin. In contrast to open neural tube defects (e.g. meningocele), spina bifida occulta does not present with elevated levels of AFP or polyhydramnios.   
❌ Meningocele :
Incorrect: Meningolocele is a type of spina bifida in which only the meninges herniate through a defect in the spinal cord. At birth, the lesion appears as a red, fleshy growth. While AFP is often elevated, the presence of polyhydramnios favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Meningomyelocele :
Incorrect: Meningomyelocele is a type of spina bifida in which both the meninges and spinal cord herniate through the defect in the spinal cord. At birth, the lesion appears as a red, fleshy growth. While AFP is often elevated, the presence of polyhydramnios favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Anencephaly :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. The patient's mother delivered the child at home and did not receive consistent prenatal care. The patient’s weight and head circumference are <5th percentile. An examination of the head is consistent with microcephaly. He is noted to have severe developmental delay with attainment of few milestones in speech, gross motor, and fine motor development. The infant cannot roll over or lift his head. An MRI of the brain is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant is presenting with developmental delay, microcephaly, and absent gyri and sulci on MRI, confirming the diagnosis of lissencephaly.     

Lissencephaly (meaning "smooth brain") is a central nervous system disorder characterized by a smooth appearance of the brain surface and lack of development of the gyri and sulci. The pathogenesis involves defective neuronal migration that normally occurs between the 12th to 24th weeks of gestation. The condition is often accompanied by other abnormalities, including microcephaly, ventriculomegaly, wide Sylvian fissures, and agenesis of the corpus callosum. The prognosis varies depending on the severity, and many patients die before the age of 10 from aspiration, respiratory disease, or seizures. Others may have severe developmental delays or near-normal development. Diagnosis can be made prenatal via ultrasound, which would demonstrate poorly-defined gyri and sulci with a smoothened appearance.   

Option Analysis

✅ Lissencephaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anencephaly :
Incorrect: Anencephaly is a type of open neural tube defect that occurs due to the failure of the rostral neuropore to close. On imaging, anencephaly is characterized by the absence of brain and calvaria. The condition is incompatible with life.   
❌ Holoprosencephaly :
Incorrect: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental brain anomaly caused by a failure of the prosencephalon (forebrain) to divide into 2 hemispheres between the 3rd and 5th week of gestation. On imaging, holoprosencephaly is characterized by a fusion of the thalami, and there is a single posteriorly located ventricle.   
❌ Dandy-Walker syndrome  :
Incorrect: Dandy-Walker malformation is a congenital malformation characterized by agenesis/hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, with cystic dilatation of the 4th ventricle and extension of the posterior fossa. On imaging, it is marked by enlargement of the cisterna magna and complete aplasia of the vermis.   
❌ Chiari II malformation:
Incorrect: Chiari II malformation is a congenital brain anomaly outlined by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis and noncommunicating hydrocephalus.

questions.text: 1-hour-old newborn girl is being evaluated in the nursery. She was born to a 23-year-old woman who did not receive prenatal care and has no significant past medical history. The patient’s mother smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day throughout the pregnancy and did not drink alcohol. The patient’s mother did not take prenatal vitamins. The patient's vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the infant is in no acute distress. Physical examination shows a raw, red lesion on the lower back. Anal sphincter tone is 0 (normal = 3), indicating no discernible pressure. The infant can move the upper extremities but not the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant is presenting with paraplegia, absent anal sphincter tone, and a raw, red lesion on the lower back, favoring the diagnosis of myelomeningocele.  

Open neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital anomalies that develop when the neural tube fails to close normally during the third and fourth weeks of gestation. NTDs may be open (e.g., myelomeningocele, meningocele, encephalocele, and anencephaly) or closed (e.g. spina bifida occulta).  

Myelomeningocele refers to a neural tube defect (NTD) in which both the meninges and neural tissue herniate through bony defect in the vertebrae. Myelomeningocele (spina bifida) is the most common NTD. The neurologic deficits vary and depend upon the level of the lesion. Signs and symptoms include sensory, motor, bladder, and bowel defects. The condition is often associated with other neurologic abnormalities including Chiari II malformation (which can result in brainstem dysfunction), hydrocephalus, learning disabilities, and tethered cord syndrome.  

Risk factors for developing closed or open neural tube defects include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Most isolated NTDs appear to be caused by folate deficiency, likely in combination with genetic or environmental risk factors.  



Option Analysis

❌ Anencephaly:
Incorrect: Anencephaly is a type of open neural tube defect that occurs due to the failure of the rostral neuropore to close, resulting in an absent calvarium and forebrain.    
❌ Meningocele:
Incorrect: Meningocele is a type of spina bifida in which only the meninges herniate through the defect in the spinal cord without neural tissue. At birth, the lesion also appears as red, fleshy growth, but since the lesion does not contain the spinal cord, patients are usually asymptomatic. The lack of anal sphincter tone and the presence of lower extremity paralysis in this patient favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Myelomeningocele:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myeloschisis:
Incorrect: Myeloschisis refers to a persistence of fibroneural stalk between the spinal cord and the overlying skin. When it extends through the spinal cord, it may result in split cord formation. This lesion instead appears as exposed, unfused neural tissue without skin or meningeal covering.  
❌ Tethered cord syndrome  :
Incorrect: Tethered cord syndrome (TCS) refers to a group of neurological disorders caused by stretch-induced dysfunction of the caudal portion of the spinal cord. It may occur independently or in association with other spinal defects (e.g. spina bifida). In toddlers, tethered cord syndrome typically presents with motor and sensory deficits, and loss of bladder control. However, the presence of unfused neural tissue in the lower back of this patient favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with worsening motor coordination. She has been frequently stumbling while playing basketball. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable aside from scoliosis. The patient does not consume illicit substances, alcohol, or tobacco. She does not take any medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 124/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Physical exam is notable for scoliosis, gait ataxia, and decreased vibratory sensation in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Her screening blood glucose level is 210 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism causing this patient’s clinical features?

choices.text: Neuronal cell loss and atrophy of the caudate and putamen
Abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase
Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple features consistent with Friedreich ataxia, including gait ataxia, diminished vibratory sensation, scoliosis, and evidence of diabetes mellitus. The disease is caused by impaired iron metabolism secondary to abnormal expression of the frataxin gene.    

Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat disorder due to GAA repeats on chromosome nine. These repeats result in limited expression of the frataxin gene, which encodes an iron binding protein that regulates iron chaperoning, detoxification, antioxidation, and mitochondrial iron storage in neurologic tissue, cardiac myocytes, and pancreatic tissue. Current theories postulate that limited frataxin causes mishandling of iron and subsequent impairment of mitochondrial functioning, causing cellular injury and oxidative stress in the affected tissue.  

Damage to neural tissue results in the clinical features of Freidrich ataxia, including limb ataxia due to spinocerebellar tract degeneration, spastic paralysis due to lateral cortiospinal tract degeneration, and decreased vibratory and proprioceptive sensation due to dorsal column degeneration. Diabetes mellitus results from damage of pancreatic beta cells, which leads to diminished insulin secretion. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy ensues due to myocyte disruption. Additional features include a high heel arch (pes cavus), hammer toes, scoliosis, nystagmus, and dysarthria.

   

Option Analysis

✅  Impaired iron regulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Neuronal cell loss and atrophy of the caudate and putamen :
Incorrect: Huntington disease results in atrophy of the caudate and putamen as well as ex vacuo ventriculomegaly. The condition is associated with increased aggression, choreiform movements, and depression. In contrast, this patient has ataxia, scoliosis, and reduced vibratory sensation, which is more concerning for Friedreich ataxia. 
❌ Abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase  :
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat expansion disorder in the DMPK gene. This disease results in abnormal myotonin protein kinase and muscle wasting. Important associated clinical features include muscle stiffness, balding, cataracts, and gonadal atrophy.  
❌ Impaired neuroplasticity:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is the most common cause of intellectual disability and is due to a CGG repeat expansion. This results in hypermethylation of the FMR1 gene, which is an important regulator of synapse formation. Clinical features associated with this disease include macroorchidism, long face with a large jaw, large everted ears, and mitral valve prolapse. 
❌ Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex:
Incorrect: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are associated with mutations in the dystrophin gene, which anchors myofilaments to the extracellular matrix. These disorders tend to present with only motor deficits but no sensory deficits (e.g. loss of vibratory sensation).

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery due to a hairy patch on the lower back. He was born to a 24-year-old primigravida who did not receive prenatal care. The patient’s mother took prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy and did not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a comfortable infant moving all 4 limbs spontaneously. Rectal examination reveals normal anal sphincter tone. Examination of the lower back shows a small, flat, hairy patch. Palpation of the area reveals a gap. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This asymptomatic newborn is presenting with a hair patch and a palpable gap (absent vertebral lamina) over the lower back, favoring the diagnosis of spina bifida occulta. 

Spinal dysraphism (spina bifida), is a type of neural tube defect which includes both open and closed defects. Open defects (e.g., meningocele, meningomyelocele) are typified by a protrusion of meninges or the meninges plus the spinal cord, through the defect, respectively. Spina bifida occulta, also known as closed spinal dysraphism, is a bony defect in which the posterior vertebral arches fail to fuse, but there is intact skin and no exposed neural tissue. The condition may occur as an isolated defect or in association with other more severe anomalies (e.g. split spinal cord malformation). Risk factors for developing spina bifida occulta include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Radiographic findings include posterior vertebral arches defect (as indicated by the red circle in the x-ray) and possibly minor anomalies of the overlying skin, such as nevi, a dermal sinus or dimple, hemangioma, underlying lipoma, or a hair patch.    





 Retrieved from: Wikipedia   

Option Analysis

✅ Spina bifida occulta:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Spondylolisthesis :
Incorrect: Spondylolisthesis is a spinal condition in which a vertebra slips forward onto the vertebrae beneath it. It is often seen in teenagers and athletes who perform activities that involve hyperextension of the spine, but it can also occur as a result of trauma or degenerative changes. On palpation, there is a step-off rather than a gap.  
❌ Meningomyelocele :
Incorrect: Meningomyelocele is a type of spina bifida in which both the meninges and spinal cord herniate through a defect in the spinal cord. At birth, the lesion appears as a red, fleshy growth. Since this defect contains portions of the spinal cord, it is more likely to present with other neurologic abnormalities (e.g., sensory, motor, bladder, and bowel defects).    
❌ Tethered cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Tethered cord syndrome (TCS) refers to a group of neurological disorders caused by stretch-induced dysfunction of the caudal portion of the spinal cord. It may occur independently or in association with other spinal defects (e.g. spina bifida). In toddlers, tethered cord syndrome typically presents with motor and sensory deficits and loss of bladder control.   
❌ Syringomyelia :
Incorrect: Syringomyelia is a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord. Most lesions occur between C2 and T9. It may be congenital (e.g. Chiari malformation type I) or acquired (e.g., postinfectious, posttraumatic). It can be asymptomatic or present with progressive central cord deficits, depending on the distribution.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old newborn boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to irritability and difficulty feeding over the past few days. Medical history is significant for a red, sac-like lesion noted shortly after birth that was located on the lower back, which presented with flaccid paralysis of the lower limbs and absence of rectal tone. The patient subsequently underwent surgery for the removal of the sac-like lesion. At present, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. An examination of the eyes is shown below:  



 Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    

The other eye reveals similar findings. This infant’s underlying condition is most likely caused by which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
The combination of irritability, difficulty feeding, and papilledema (all indicative of increased intracranial pressure), along with a recent spinal surgery for a symptomatic sac-like lesion on the lower back (myelomeningocele), is suggestive of Chiari type II malformation. Chiari malformations are a heterogeneous group of congenital disorders typified by anatomic anomalies of the cerebellum and brainstem, with downward herniation of the cerebellum into the spinal canal.  

Chiari II malformation is defined by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils (mnemonic: type 2 includes 2 structure) via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis and noncommunicating hydrocephalus (which leads to increased intracranial pressure). Chiari II malformation is often seen with myelomeningocele and is more likely to present early in life. Myelomeningocele is a type of open neural tube defect typified by herniation of the meninges and the spinal cord through a bony defect. The presentation depends upon the level of the lesion and usually involves sensory, motor, bowel, and bladder deficits.

In contrast, Chiari I malformation involves the downward displacement of only the cerebellar tonsils, is associated with syringomyelia, and usually presents in adolescence or adulthood.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Infection:
Incorrect: Meningitis in a newborn does tend to present with nonspecific signs such as irritability and difficulty feeding. However, the vitals in this case are normal, and the presence of papilledema suggests another diagnosis.    
❌ Malignancy :
Incorrect: Intracranial tumors can lead to increased intracranial pressure and papilledema as seen here; however, the combination of a recent spinal surgery for a sac-like lesion and the presence of increased intracranial pressure on exam favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Herniation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autoimmune :
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy) is an autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of Schwann cells. It does present with flaccid paralysis, but it would not present with signs of increased intracranial pressure. Furthermore, this patient’s history of surgical correction for a spinal lesion (likely a myelomeningocele) favors a different diagnosis.  
❌ Ischemic :
Incorrect: Conditions that might affect the blood flow to the brain include conditions such as stroke, vasculitis, and sickle cell disease. However, the combination of a recent spinal surgery for a sac-like lesion and the evidence of increased intracranial pressure favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of neck pain and headaches. His symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past several months, and his headache is located primarily at the occipital region. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. He is not taking any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have down beating nystagmus. MRI imaging of the brain reveals the following findings:  

 Image reproduced from Radiopaedia  

 Which of the following findings is most often associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cystic cavity within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a chronic, worsening headache, nystagmus, and evidence of tonsillar ectopia on the sagittal view of his brain MRI. These findings are consistent with symptomatic Chiari I malformation, which is most commonly associated with a syrinx, or cystic cavity, within the spinal cord.    

A Chiari I malformation is a congenital condition characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that are displaced below the level of the foramen magnum. Most cases of Chiari I malformation are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. When symptomatic, patients typically present during adolescence or early adulthood with chronic occipital headaches, cranial nerve palsies, paresthesias, ataxia, or nystagmus.    

Furthermore, nearly half of all cases are associated with a syringomyelia in the spinal cord. If this cystic cavity enlarges, it can compress the anterior white commissure, resulting in a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in upper extremities but with preservation of fine touch. Other causes of syringomyelia include trauma and tumors.  

Figure 1: Cerebellar tonsils (white arrow) seen herniating below foramen magnum (white line)

Option Analysis

✅ Cystic cavity within the spinal cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lumbosacral myelomeningocele:
Incorrect: Chiari II malformations are associated with lumbosacral myelomeningoceles. Chiari II malformations are due to downward displacement of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils. The condition is almost universally discovered at birth since it leads to significant motor and sensory deficits. 
❌ Presence of a monoventricle:
Incorrect: Holoprosencephaly refers to the failure of the embryonic forebrain to separate into two distinct compartments during fetal development. The condition results in a monoventricle. However, this patient’s symptoms are most consistent with those of a Chiari I malformation, which would not lead to the presence of a monoventricle. 
❌ Non-communicating hydrocephalus :
Incorrect: This patient’s imaging shows a herniated cerebellar tonsil, which is concerning for a Chiari I malformation. Non-communicating hydrocephalus can occur due to Chiari I malformations. However, it is overall a rare complication and more likely to occur in patients with Chiari II malformations.  
❌  Morbid obesity  :
Incorrect: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) can manifest with headaches and visual disturbances. The condition is associated with morbid obesity. However, IIH is not associated with Chiari I malformation, which is characterized by herniated cerebellar tonsils on neuroimaging.

questions.text: A 5-month-old female infant is brought to her pediatrician for a well-child visit. The mother describes that the patient “hasn’t been breathing well lately, and I’ve noticed that she doesn’t have a very loud cry.” The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 90/54 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Her physical exam is notable for flaccid upper extremities and an inability to sit unsupported. Reflexes are diminished in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following best describes the underlying genetic pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Loss of function of mutation of superoxide dismutase 1

questions.solution:
This infant presents with signs of lower motor neuron disease including an inability to sit unsupported, diminished deep tendon reflexes, and flaccid upper extremities. In the infantile period, this constellation of symptoms raises concern for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type I, which is also termed Werdig-Hoffman disease.  

SMA type 1 is due to an autosomal recessive mutation in SMN1. This gene encodes a protein referred to as survival motor neuron protein, which functions in transcriptional regulation, telomerase regeneration, cellular trafficking, as well as neuronal trafficking and differentiation. In this disease, microdeletions disrupt this protein and result in congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord.    

This degeneration produces symptoms of lower motor neuron disease including weakness, fasciculations (especially of the tongue), and hypotonia. In infants, additional findings include the inability to sit unsupported, poor cry, difficulty feeding, and recurrent aspiration. Most infants die before the age of two years due to respiratory failure and recurrent pneumonia.  


Option Analysis

✅ Autosomal recessive mutation in SMN1   :
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Loss of function of mutation of superoxide dismutase 1:
Incorrect: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (also termed Lou Gehirg’s disease) is a combined upper and lower motor neuron disease. It is associated with loss of function mutations in SOD1 and tends to present in middle or older aged individuals. This patient does not have clinical features of upper motor neuron disease (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia), making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ TSC2 mutation on chromosome 16  :
Incorrect: Tuberous sclerosis is a multiple organ disease resulting in hamartomas in multiple organ systems including the brain. It tends to present with seizures and intellectual disability rather than signs of lower motor neuron disease. 
❌ Autosomal dominant PMP22 gene duplication:
Incorrect: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is an autosomal dominant polyneuropathy that results in both motor and sensory dysfunction. Associated clinical features include hammer toes and pes cavus. In contrast, this patient does not have sensory deficits. 
❌ Autosomal dominant CAG repeat expansion:
Incorrect: Huntington disease is a trinucleotide repeat expansion disease that results in symptoms of chorea, athetosis, and aggression. It does not typically present with features of lower motor neuron disease, and it presents in adults, as opposed to children.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old newborn boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to irritability and difficulty feeding over the past few days. He was born through normal vaginal birth and delivery to a 24-year-old primigravida woman who did not receive prenatal care. The patient’s family history is unremarkable. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On physical examination, frontal bossing and prominent scalp veins are noted. Generalized spasticity is present in all limbs. Examination of the skin shows a hair patch over the lower back with a gap under the skin. An MRI of the brain is obtained and shown below:  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant is presenting with signs of congenital hydrocephalus (e.g., frontal bossing, prominent scalp veins) and signs of increased intracranial pressure (evidenced by bradycardia, hypertension, and irritability). The MRI reveals a hypoplasia or agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, which is characteristic of Dandy-Walker malformation. The hair patch signifies an underlying spina bifida occulta.

Dandy-Walker is a rare congenital malformation marked by agenesis or hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis (indicated by the red circle on the head MRI), with cystic dilatation of the 4th ventricle and extension of the posterior fossa. Clinical presentation is dependent on the severity of the anomaly. The majority of patients usually present with signs and symptoms of hydrocephalus and associated neurological symptoms in the first year of life. The condition is often associated with spina bifida (occulta, meningocele, or myelomeningocele).    







Option Analysis

❌ Chiari I malformation:
Incorrect: Chiari I malformation is a congenital brain anomaly characterized by herniation of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum. The condition is usually asymptomatic during childhood and manifests in adulthood with headaches, elevated intracranial pressure, and cranial neuropathies. It often occurs in conjunction with syringomyelia, which is a cavitation within the central canal of the spinal cord. This patient’s MRI favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Chiari II malformation:
Incorrect: Chiari II malformation is a congenital brain anomaly characterized by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis, and noncommunicating hydrocephalus. Chiari II is often seen with myelomeningocele and is more likely to present early in life. However, this patient’s MRI favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Dandy-Walker malformation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lissencephaly:
Incorrect: Lissencephaly (meaning "smooth brain") is a central nervous system disorder characterized by a smooth appearance of the brain surface due to the lack of development of gyri and sulci. The pathogenesis involves defective neuronal migration, which normally occurs between the 12th to 24th weeks of gestation. This patient’s MRI favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Anencephaly :
Incorrect: Anencephaly is a type of open neural tube defect that occurs due to the failure of the rostral neuropore to close. On ultrasound or other imaging modality, anencephaly demonstrates the absence of brain and calvaria. The condition is incompatible with life, and infants die in utero or soon after birth.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to progressively worsening headaches over the past year. Medical history is unremarkable, other than mild scoliosis. Over the past year, he has been experiencing dull, diffuse headaches, especially in the morning. He also noted occasional blurry vision but did not seek care. Vital signs are normal. On physical examination, mild bilateral papilledema is noted. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. A brain MRI is obtained and shown below. This patient’s condition is also associated with which of the following findings?  


Retrieved from: Radiopaedia

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation in upper extremities
Herniation of the spinal cord via a vertebral defect
Progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, spastic limb weakness, and normal sensation

questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy boy is now presenting with progressive headaches which are more pronounced in the morning, raising concerns for an intracranial process. The brain MRI reveals a classic picture of cerebellar tonsillar herniation, favoring the diagnosis of Chiari type I malformation, which is associated with syringomyelia.   

Chiari I malformation is characterized by the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils inferior to foramen magnum (mnemonic: type 1 includes 1 structure). This finding is indicated by the red circle, showing caudal displacement of the cerebellar tonsils on head MRI. The condition is usually asymptomatic during childhood and manifests in adolescence and adulthood with occipital headaches, elevated intracranial pressure, and neck pain. The condition often occurs in conjunction with syringomyelia, which is a cavitation within the central canal of the spinal cord that results in a bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities (“cape like” distribution).  

In contrast, Chiari II malformation is marked by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils (mnemonic: type 2 includes 2 structure) via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis, and noncommunicating hydrocephalus. Chiari II is often seen with myelomeningocele and is more likely to present early in life.  

 


Option Analysis

✅ Loss of pain and temperature sensation in upper extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Herniation of the spinal cord via a vertebral defect:
Incorrect: This answer describes a myelomeningocele, a congenital open neural tube defect typified by herniation of the meninges and the spinal cord through a vertebral bony defect. The presentation depends upon the level of the lesion and usually involves sensory, motor and bowel and bladder deficits. This condition, however, is associated with Chiari type II, rather than type I. Also, it is more likely to present in infancy, and this patient has a normal medical history.   
❌ Progressive symmetric ascending muscle paralysis:
Incorrect: This answer depicts Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy), an autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of Schwann cells. It is often associated with gastrointestinal infections, such as Campylobacter jejuni.  
❌ Progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, spastic limb weakness, and normal sensation  :
Incorrect: This answer depicts amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a neurologic condition characterized by both upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs. Patients often present with bulbar palsy (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia) and flaccid or spastic limb weakness. This condition is not associated with Chiari malformations.   
❌ Progressive sensory ataxia:
Incorrect: This answer depicts tabes dorsalis, a condition seen in patients with tertiary syphilis. It is characterized by degeneration and demyelination of dorsal columns that carry proprioceptive coordination. Patients present with progressive sensory ataxia, positive Romberg sign and absent deep tendon reflexes.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She did not receive prenatal care. The estimated gestation age is 25 weeks based on last menstrual period. The mother did not take prenatal vitamins. She did not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs during the pregnancy. Twenty minutes later, she gives birth to a stillborn male. An autopsy is performed and reveals the following:    



Retrieved from: Wikipedia

A defect in which of the following processes during embryogenesis most likely led to this condition?

choices.text: Failure of the primordial brain to divide
Failure of neural crest cell migration
Failure of the facial processes to fuse
Failure of fusion of the lateral palatine shelves

questions.solution:
This autopsy shows a classic picture of anencephaly, a severe developmental defect typified by failure of the forebrain and variable amounts of the brainstem to develop properly. The calvaria is open without overlying skin, exposing the cranial neural tube.  The condition is incompatible with life, and infants are either stillborn or die in the first few hours/days of life.  

The central nervous system starts to develop from an area of thickened ectoderm, known as the neural plate, around the 3rd week of embryonic life. Later, the lateral edges of the neural plate enlarge to form the neural folds and fuse into the neural tube. The fusion process begins in the cervical area and continues in both the rostral and caudal directions. Anencephaly is due to failure of the rostral neuropore to close around postovulatory day 25. These pregnancies are often complicated by polyhydramnios because the part of the brain responsible for swallowing is absent, resulting in increased fluid in the amniotic sac (polyhydramnios).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Failure of the primordial brain to divide:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis behind holoprosencephaly, a developmental disorder in which the prosencephalon (the forebrain) fails to divide into two hemispheres. Instead, this picture is consistent with anencephaly.  
❌ Failure of neural crest cell migration:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis behind Hirschsprung disease, a congenital defect that is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells/enteric nervous plexuses (Auerbach and Meissner plexuses) in the distal colon. Infants with Hirschsprung disease typically present with bilious emesis, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium.   
✅ Failure of neuropore to close  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Failure of the facial processes to fuse :
Incorrect: This answer describes the defect underlying craniofacial clefts, a facial deformity characterized by a gap or excess tissue of bone and/or soft tissue. This condition is associated with airway/breathing deficits, as well as feeding and speech deficits. Unlike the anencephaly seen in this newborn, craniofacial clefts are compatible with life.   
❌ Failure of fusion of the lateral palatine shelves  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the defect underlying cleft palate. Another cause of this condition involves failure of the palatine shelf to fuse with the nasal septum and/or the primary palate (formation of 2° palate). Instead, this picture is consistent with anencephaly.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling two stories while washing windows on scaffolding. Per paramedics, the patient fell directly on his back, was helmeted, and did not suffer the loss of consciousness. On arrival, temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 178/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient’s primary survey is intact. The patient's secondary survey is notable for bruising and tenderness over the cervical and thoracic spine. A neurological examination demonstrates loss of sensation starting below the xiphoid process. The patient has 2+ triceps and brachioradialis reflexes and 5/5 strength of the upper extremities bilaterally. The patient is unable to move the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following reflects the most likely level of spinal injury?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for trauma evaluation after sustaining an injury to the spine. The neurologic examination is consistent with preserved sensation and motor strength above the level of T7, which is best approximated at the xiphoid process level.    

Pathologies that affect the spinal cord are diverse and include trauma, ischemia, infection, autoimmune conditions, neoplasm, and hereditary-degenerative diseases. Compressive etiologies (e.g. those resulting in direct physical impingement on the spinal cord) include tumors, spinal epidural abscesses, hematomas, herniated disks, or bony disease. Spinal cord transection can also result from direct trauma such as stab wounds, gunshot wounds, or extreme shearing forces. Ischemia, particularly from the anterior or posterior spinal arteries, may also result in injury to the spinal cord.    

Regardless of the etiology, the level of injury can be determined via a focused neurological assessment, including sensation testing, motor function testing, and reflex testing. The absence of sensation below a particular dermatome in conjunction with correlating motor and reflex deficits can indicate the level of a lesion.  


Option Analysis

✅ T7:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ T4:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at T4 would present with loss of sensation below the nipple line; this patient has preserved sensation at this dermatome.  
❌ C2:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at C2 would result in loss of sensation below the posterior half of the skull; injuries to this spinal level are often lethal due to damage to brainstem structures.  
❌ C4:
Incorrect: Injury to the C4 level would result in loss of sensation below the collar line and possible diaphragmatic dysfunction since this spinal cord level helps innervate the diaphragm.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: A spinal cord lesion at T10 would result in loss of sensation starting at the level of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to a primary care clinic by his partner for evaluation of ongoing behavioral problems. The patient has a long history of aggressive behavioral outbursts and is known to be apathetic and unapologetic for his actions. Past medical history includes blunt head trauma at age 22 after being struck in the head with an iron rod. Prior to the accident, the patient was well-mannered and an excellent student; however, after the accident, he became progressively distractible, disobedient towards adults of authority, and quarrelsome. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Damage to which of the following cortical areas is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s behavioral changes?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits abnormal behavior including aggression, distractibility, apathy, and impulsivity. These changes in behavior are reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.  

The prefrontal cortex is located anterior to the precentral area in the frontal lobe and includes the superior, middle, and inferior frontal gyri. It harbors both afferent and efferent pathways to and from the thalamus, hypothalamus, cerebral cortex, and the corpus striatum. The prefrontal cortex governs personality, social behavior, and executive functions, including decision making, reasoning, and emotional regulation.  

Damage to the prefrontal cortex results in disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior. Re-emergence of primitive reflexes are often observed.

Damage to the prefrontal cortex can occur secondary to trauma, cerebrovascular disease, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease (e.g. fronto-temporal dementia).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Prefrontal cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Broca’s area:
Incorrect: Broca’s area lies at the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere and has connections to the motor cortex – specifically to areas that control the muscles of the larynx, mouth, soft palate, and the tongue, as well as muscles of respiration. The primary function of this area includes formation, or production, of words and speech. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Wernicke’s area:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area encompasses a portion of the superior temporal gyrus along with the supramarginal and angular gyri of the parietal lobe. This area of the brain is responsible for comprehending written and spoken language. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Rostral to the premotor cortex and extending into the middle frontal gyrus is the frontal eye field, which controls voluntary eye movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity and integrates both sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motorcycle accident. The patient was struck by a car and sustained blunt head trauma with associated loss of consciousness. He quickly regained consciousness, but he did not seek care because he was “feeling fine.” Several hours later, he developed a severe headache with associated nausea and vomiting, and his partner called emergency services. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient responds to painful stimuli only. Ocular examination demonstrates a dilated right pupil. A non-contrast CT is obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures was most likely injured in this patient?  


Retrieved from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with an epidural hematoma due to middle meningeal artery rupture. Following the accident, the patient sustained a characteristic “lucid interval,” which refers to a temporary improvement in the condition before clinical deterioration from hematoma expansion. On presentation, the constellation of bradycardia, hypertension with a wide pulse pressure, and respiratory depression with irregular breathing raises concern for the Cushing triad (reflective of elevated intracranial hypertension and brain stem compression). Lastly, the physical examination demonstrates a dilated pupil, which is concerning for uncal herniation and compression of the cranial nerve III.  

The majority of cases of epidural hematoma occur secondary to head trauma during accidents, falls, and assaults. The most commonly implicated vessel is the middle meningeal artery as it passes under the pterion–the confluence where the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones merge. On head CT, epidural bleeding creates a lens-shaped lesion as the collection is bordered by dural attachments at the cranial sutures. Treatment of epidural hematoma involves an emergency craniotomy and hematoma evacuation.



Option Analysis

❌ Bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of the bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas. The CT findings above demonstrating a lens shaped lesion are consistent with an epidural hematoma. The CT in a subdural hematoma would instead demonstrate a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.  
❌ Lenticulostriate arteries:
Incorrect: Rupture of the lenticulostriate arteries manifests with intraparenchymal hemorrhage. It is more commonly associated with chronic hypertension (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms), rather than trauma.  
❌ Carotid artery:
Incorrect: Carotid dissection may occur in young patients in the setting of trauma. More common manifestations include neck pain or stiffness, Horner syndrome, and stroke-like symptoms. Aside from trauma, this patient has no risk factors for carotid dissection (e.g. connective tissue disorder). Furthermore, carotid dissection is not associated with a “lucid interval.”  
✅ Middle meningeal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Middle cerebral artery rupture manifests in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which may occur in patients with a saccular aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations. Patients often endorse the “worst headache of my life.” On CT, SAH appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by his partner after being found unresponsive one hour ago. The patient fell down a flight of stairs the previous evening, but he appeared fine immediately afterwards, and he went to bed at his usual time. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/102 mm Hg. On examination, the right pupil is 5 mm and fixed. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light. There is an extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination demonstrates a systolic click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is started. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows a right-sided 6-cm subdural hematoma with an 18-mm midline shift and associated cerebral edema. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Right eye esotropia and upward deviation

questions.solution:
This patient has a large right-sided subdural hematoma, resulting in elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral edema, presenting as midline shift and transtentorial herniation of the uncus.

With this type of herniation, the uncus (the innermost portion of the temporal lobe) slips down towards the tentorium and compresses parts of the brain stem. The following neurologic deficits are commonly observed with transtentorial herniation of the uncus:

  •  CN III nerve palsy, where the eye is fixed in a “down and out” position with a dilated and unresponsive pupil. 
  •  Posterior cerebral artery compression leads to contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.  
  •  Paramedian basilar artery injury results in small linear or flame-shaped hemorrhages called Duret hemorrhages. 
  •  Contralateral hemiparesis is secondary to compression of the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle of the midbrain, damaging corticospinal fibers. 
  •  Contralateral peduncle compression against the tentorium results in ipsilateral hemiparesis, known as a false localizing sign, the so-called Kernohan's notch. 

Option Analysis

❌ Right eye esotropia and upward deviation  :
Incorrect: Right eye esotropia and elevation would be caused by concomitant CN IV and VI palsies, leading to unopposed CN III activity. When CN III is unopposed, the associated extraocular muscles produce adduction and elevation or depression of the eye. Instead, uncal herniation causes CN III palsy, resulting in pupillary dilation and absent light reflex (as seen in this patient), abduction, and slight depression of the eye (“down and out” gaze).  
❌ Multifocal myoclonus  :
Incorrect: Multifocal myoclonus is associated with various neurologic disorders, including seizures. It is more frequently observed in severe cerebral hypoxia, progressive myoclonic epilepsy, neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer disease), or metabolic coma (e.g. secondary to glycemic disturbances). However, it is not a common symptom of uncal herniation.  
❌ Left-side vagus nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) exits the brainstem via the medulla, which lies at a position too inferior to be affected by uncal herniation. CN X can be injured via direct trauma to the neck and can also occur due to compression from an aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Bilateral vestibulocochlear nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII can be injured by hemorrhage or aneurysms of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  
✅ Right-sided hemiplegia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the back. The patient was the victim of a robbery and was shot while attempting to flee the scene. Temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the patient's secondary survey is notable for a single gunshot wound at the T10 spinal level without an exit wound. An emergent MRI demonstrates complete transection of the spinal cord at the level of T10.  Which of the following neurologic deficits are most likely to be expected based on this patient's spinal cord injury?

choices.text: Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation after sustaining a gunshot wound that results in a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T10. At this level, neurologic deficits to be expected would be a total loss of sensation at the level of the umbilicus and loss of motor function of the bilateral lower extremities.   

The spinal cord is divided into several different cross-sectional anatomic tracts and levels based on the corresponding vertebrae; an injury at any one of these levels or within the anatomic tract results in distinct neurologic deficits. During a spinal cord transection, the patient loses all sensation and voluntary movement inferior to the lesion site. For example, if a transaction occurs between C4 and C5, the patient will lose all motor and sensory functions below this level, rendering them quadriplegic.  If transection happens between C6 and C8, there’s a complete loss of lower limb function combined with a loss of hand and a variable amount of upper limb function.  

Damage to specific tracts can also occur via partial spinal cord transection. For example, Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that arises following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to damage to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure).  



Option Analysis

✅ Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T7, not T10.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C5. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C3. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only  :
Incorrect: This choice is not a physically realistic possibility. Complete loss of sensation at the neckline without the involvement of lower extremity weakness would not occur.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate acute-on-chronic low back pain. Several years ago, the patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer, but he elected to forego treatment and was lost to follow-up. Today, the patient was brought in by family members after he could not get out of bed. The patient states, “I can’t lift my legs, and I woke up covered in my stool.” The patient has no other significant medical history or medication use. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows a cachectic male in moderate distress. The patient has diffuse lumbar spinal tenderness to palpation and 2/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally. The patient’s pelvic x-ray is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features most indicates this patient’s clinical condition?


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of prostate cancer presents for evaluation of acute-on-chronic low back pain with associated bowel dysfunction, motor deficits in the lower extremities, and a pelvic x-ray demonstrating numerous osteoblastic lesions consistent with metastatic disease. This clinical presentation is suspicious for cauda equina syndrome, and urinary retention is a particularly specific finding for this condition.    
Cauda equina syndrome refers to a spinal cord injury caudal to the conus that injures two or more nerve roots, often via direct compression of the cauda equina within the lumbar spinal canal. The disease has multiple etiologies, including ankylosing spondylitis, chemotherapy, disc herniation, osteomyelitis, spinal epidural abscess, neoplasm, hematoma, arteriovenous malformations, inferior vena cava thrombosis, or trauma.  

The most common presenting complaint is acute-on-chronic low back pain; however, the associated features vary. In general, most patients have a combination of back pain, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and symptoms of radiculopathy. Additional findings include lower extremity weakness and diminished sensation in the distribution of multiple nerve roots (L3-S1), peri-anal numbness, and loss of anal sphincter tone. This disorder, while rare, carries significant morbidity, often resulting in permanent neurologic dysfunction if left untreated. When suspected, management includes emergent MRI of the lumbar spine and neurosurgical consultation.



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: The absence of deep tendon reflexes is often found in patients with cauda equina syndrome; however, it is not a specific feature of this condition as it may be found in simple, unilateral radiculopathy as well.  
❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: Hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia, is more commonly found in patients with cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Preserved perineal sensation :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome usually exhibits sensory loss in the perineal area (saddle anesthesia).  
❌ Increased anal sphincter tone :
Incorrect: Decreased, not increased, anal sphincter tone is observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent sciatica symptoms. The patient has had low back pain that radiates down the back of his left leg for weeks after he fell while skiing. The patient states, “The symptoms are getting so bad that I feel the leg is getting weaker. I’ve tried physical therapy, but it does not work.” The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has 4/5 strength with plantar flexion and a 1+ ankle jerk reflex on physical examination of the left leg. The right leg has 5/5 strength and full reflexes. Which of the following myotomes is most likely affected based on this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of persistent sciatica and has evidence of S1 radiculopathy given this patient’s clinical findings of pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion and diminished ankle jerk reflex.   

Deep tendon reflexes can provide valuable information regarding the level of spinal cord involvement or damage to a particular nerve route. When this reflex is triggered, stretch receptors in the muscle-tendon send afferent impulses to the spinal cord through their cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion, which then synapse with alpha motor neurons. Alpha motor neurons then transmit an automatic efferent signal back to the muscle leading to a contraction.    

Critical deep tendon reflexes include the brachioradialis and biceps tendon, which test myotome C5 and C6; the triceps tendon, which tests C6, C7, and C8; the patellar tendon, which tests L2, L3, and L4; and the Achilles tendon, which tests S1 and S2. Hyperactive reflexes indicate an upper motor neuron problem within the spinal cord or central nervous system, whereas hypoactive reflexes indicate peripheral nerve pathology.  


Option Analysis

✅ S1-S2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 is the myotome reflecting the knee jerk reflex, which is elicited by tapping on the patellar tendon while the knee flexes.  
❌ S3-S4:
Incorrect: S3-S4 is the myotome reflecting the anal wink reflex. This reflex may be absent in cauda equina syndrome due to compression of these nerve roots.  
❌ L1-L2:
Incorrect: L1-L2 are the myotomes associated with the cremasteric reflex, which will often be diminished in cases of testicular torsion.  
❌ C5-C6:
Incorrect: The C5-C6 myotome is associated with the biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, which are not implicated in this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department as a level 1 trauma following a fall from scaffolding. The patient worked as a painter and slipped and fell approximately 20 ft, landing on his back. Upon arrival, the patient has a GCS of 15 and endorses pain in his lower back. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and his secondary survey is notable for a step-off and pain at the T12-L1 spinal level. An emergent MRI of the spine is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features is most specific to this patient's clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation following back trauma and has an MRI that demonstrates a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body with subsequent compression on the conus medullaris. This neurosurgical emergency presents with all the clinical features of cauda equina syndrome, plus upper motor neuron deficits such as hyperreflexia.    

Conus medullaris syndrome is a rare neurosurgical emergency that refers to compression of the conus medullaris from trauma, spinal epidural abscess, hematoma, or disc herniation. This pathologic entity presents with many overlapping features of cauda equina syndrome, including acute lower back pain with associated lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction.  

Key differentiating features of conus medullaris syndrome include the presence of upper motor neuron deficits (e.g. hyperreflexia, increased tone) and symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness. The latter may be mild if the lesion is restricted and spares both the lumbar cord and the adjacent sacral and lumbar nerve roots. In addition, conus medullaris syndrome is more commonly implicated in spinal lesions from T12-L1 since the spinal cord terminates as the conus medullaris at this level in most adult patients. Trauma or lesions below this spinal level are unlikely to result in conus medullaris syndrome.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Saddle anesthesia :
Incorrect: Saddle anesthesia is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific.  
❌ Asymmetric lower extremity weakness:
Incorrect: Symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness is more likely to be found in patients with conus medullaris syndrome; however, it can also be observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome and is therefore nonspecific.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Urinary retention is found in both conditions and is not specific to conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Decreased bulbocavernosus reflex:
Incorrect: A decreased bulbocavernosus reflex is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific to either condition.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman sustains a brain injury after a motor vehicle accident. The patient cannot form memories of events taking place after the accident, including her hospital stay and subsequent time spent recovering at home. However, she can recall events that occurred before the accident.  

Which of the following brain structures was most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has anterograde amnesia. The condition can arise due to injury to the hippocampus, part of the limbic system.    

The limbic system is a group of brain structures located lateral to the thalamus, beneath the cerebral cortex, and above the brainstem. The limbic system regulates emotions, memory, olfaction, and autonomic functions associated with homeostasis. Although this system consists of many structures, the hippocampus, amygdala, and hypothalamus are the main ones.  

The hippocampus is involved in transferring short-term memory to long-term memory. As a result, damage to this structure would result in anterograde amnesia.  

The amygdala processes emotional responses, such as fear and anxiety. The amygdala sends outputs to multiple structures (e.g., hypothalamus, thalamic nuclei, and trigeminal and facial nerves) to increase autonomic activity and control facial expressions.  

Finally, the hypothalamus helps facilitate communication between different limbic system components and is vital in maintaining homeostasis. It helps regulate hunger and satiety, thirst, sleep-wake cycle, and sexual desire. Furthermore, the hypothalamus regulates hormone release from the pituitary gland.



Option Analysis

❌ Structure A:
Incorrect: Structure A is the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus regulates homeostasis by controlling hunger and satiety, thirst, sleep-wake cycle, and sexual desire. Furthermore, the hypothalamus regulates hormone release from the pituitary gland.
