Hypothalamic injury would more likely present with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., hyperthermia, poikilothermia) or endocrine abnormalities (e.g., amenorrhea, hypothyroidism) instead of anterograde amnesia. 
❌ Structure B:
Incorrect: Structure B is the olfactory bulb. Damage to this structure may cause anosmia (inability to smell) but not anterograde amnesia. 
❌  Structure C :
Incorrect: Structure C is the amygdala. Although this structure assists memory formation, it is more significantly involved in regulating the body’s response to fear. Damage to the bilateral amygdala can cause Kluver-Bucy syndrome, which manifests with a diminished fear response, hypersexuality, hyperorality, and emotional blunting. 
❌ Structure D:
Incorrect: Structure D is the part of the cerebellum involved in coordination and balance. The cerebellum is not involved in the formation of new memories. As a result, injury to this structure would not give rise to this patient's anterograde amnesia. 
✅ Structure E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient is unresponsive, and the paramedics report a witnessed generalized-tonic-clonic seizure. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. On examination, the patient appears comatose with mispositioned and fixed pupils. The upper extremities are adducted, extended, and in hyperpronation. The lower extremities appear extended, adducted, and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. A non-contrast CT scan of the head demonstrates extensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage with a horizontal shift of midline structures. Damage to which of the following anatomic structures most likely contributed to the extensor posturing observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage that is complicated by brain herniation (coma, mispositioned and fixed pupils, and rigid extension of upper and lower extremities).

Abnormal posturing secondary to brain herniation results from disruption of the descending tracts (e.g. rubrospinal and vestibulospinal tracts) involved in reflexive and postural movements. The red nucleus in the midbrain gives rise to the rubrospinal tract, which acts on the proximal flexor musculature of the upper limbs.  
 
  •  Transection or injury to the brainstem at the level of the red nucleus or below the red nucleus (pons) damages the rubrospinal tract. Spared vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts overstimulate extensor muscles, leading to the characteristic decerebrate/extensor posturing where the upper extremities are adducted, extended and in hyperpronation, while the lower extremities are also extended, adducted and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. 
 
  •  Damage above the level of the red nucleus (e.g. cerebral hemisphere and internal capsule) over stimulates the flexor muscles of the upper extremities. The unaffected vestibulospinal and pontine reticulospinal tracts stimulate the extensor muscles of the body leading to decorticate/flexion posturing, where upper extremities are adducted and flexed with wrists, hands and fingers flexed into fists near the chest, while the lower extremities remain extended and internally rotated with feet in plantarflexion and big toes pointing medially. 


Option Analysis

❌ Locus coeruleus  :
Incorrect:  The locus coeruleus houses norepinephrine secreting neurons that participate in fight and flight responses during physical and emotional stress. It is located in the dorsal pons and does not affect the motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
✅ Red nucleus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raphe nuclei  :
Incorrect: The raphe nuclei are located in the midbrain, pons, and medulla and project widely through the CNS. They house serotonergic neurons which play a role in sleep-wake cycle, anxiety, psychosis and mood changes. They do not affect motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
❌ Substantia nigra:
Incorrect: The substantia nigra contains dopaminergic neurons, which are depleted in Parkinson disease. This disease presents with bradykinesia, involuntary tremor, and rigidity.  
❌ Nucleus basalis of Meynert  :
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis of Meynert houses the cell bodies of cholinergic neurons. Decreased acetylcholine is released from these neurons in patients with Alzheimer disease.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of headache, nausea, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. His partner states he has been more irritable and has had trouble remembering to do routine errands. Two weeks ago, the patient fell while skiing but did not seek medical evaluation. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, furosemide, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient is ill-appearing. He is oriented to person, but not to place or time. During the examination, the patient is unable to answer questions or follow commands. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right and 2+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the right. There is 4/5 weakness of the right hip flexors. The patient’s non-contrast head CT is demonstrated below.

Reproduced from Radiopedia

Disruption of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of headache, nausea, and vomiting following trauma, along with head CT demonstrating a crescent-shaped lesion, is consistent with a diagnosis of subdural hematoma (SDH). The skiing accident likely induced shearing of the bridging cortical veins, with subsequent hematoma formation.    

Rupture of bridging cortical veins results in hemorrhage between the arachnoid mater and dura mater. Common causes include blunt head trauma (e.g. high-energy impact due to motor vehicle accidents), acceleration-deceleration injury, and cerebral atrophy (in older adults). Symptoms of SDH usually develop gradually 1-2 days after the initial injury and include impaired consciousness, confusion, or symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea/vomiting). Patients may also develop focal neurological deficits (e.g. contralateral hemiparesis). Non-contrast CT scan will demonstrate a crescent-shaped hypodensity that crosses cranial suture lines.   

The difference between subdural, epidural, and subarachnoid hemorrhage is summarized below:



Option Analysis

✅ Cortical bridging veins :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Berry aneurysm:
Incorrect: Rupture of a berry aneurysm can result in subarachnoid hemorrhage; however, this patient’s CT demonstrates a subdural hemorrhage.  
❌ Posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Rupture of the posterior communicating artery can result in a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which usually manifests as a severe headache, often described as the “worst headache of my life.” This patient’s CT instead demonstrates a subdural hemorrhage.  
❌ Middle meningeal artery:
Incorrect: Fracture at the pterion can result in an epidural hematoma due to hemorrhage from the underlying middle meningeal artery. An epidural hematoma is diagnosed with a non-contrast CT scan demonstrating a biconvex, hyperdense mass confined to the suture lines between the dura mater and the skull. 
❌ Lateral striate artery:
Incorrect: The lateral striate arteries arise from the middle cerebral arteries (also known as lenticulostriate arteries). These vessels supply the internal capsule and basal ganglia. This patient’s CT instead demonstrates a subdural hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was unresponsive and subsequently had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during transport. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, and cocaine misuse. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg. The patient is comatose with downward, fixed pupils and rigid extension of the upper and lower extremities bilaterally on physical examination. A cross-sectional CT scan demonstrates complete obliteration of the perimesencephalic and premedullary cisterns and a truncated brainstem with Duret hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a traumatic brain injury and intraparenchymal hemorrhage progressing to brain herniation. Mass effect from intracranial hemorrhage can raise the intracranial pressure (ICP), ultimately leading to the physiologic effects of hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea (Cushing triad). With hemorrhage expansion, central/downward brain herniation may occur.

In central herniation, the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes of both cerebral hemispheres herniate through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. As the brainstem becomes inferiorly displaced, damage to the midbrain and upper pons results in mid-positioned and fixed pupils due to loss of sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation. In addition, paralysis of upward eye movement occurs, leading to the sunset eyes sign (eyes appear driven downward). Duret hemorrhages (due to the rupture of paramedian basilar artery branches) can be seen in central herniation. Brain herniation also results in abnormal posturing due to the disruption of the descending tract typically involved in reflexive and postural movements (which accounts for the decerebrate posturing seen in this patient).  

Option Analysis

❌ Subfalcine herniation:
Incorrect: Subfalcine herniation occurs when the innermost portion of the frontal lobe herniates under a portion of the falx cerebri. This injury does not put as much pressure on the brainstem as the other types of herniation but does compress the anterior cerebral artery manifesting in dysarthria and leg weakness. This patient’s presentation is instead suggestive of central/downward herniation.  
✅ Downward transtentorial herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upward herniation  :
Incorrect: Increased pressure in the posterior fossa can cause the cerebellum to move up through the tentorial opening and push the midbrain through the tentorial notch. Patients typically present with nausea and vomiting with rapid progression to a depressed level of consciousness and death. This patient’s presentation suggests central/downward herniation secondary to increased intracranial pressure.  
❌ Cerebellar tonsillar herniation  :
Incorrect: In tonsillar herniation, the cerebellar tonsils move downward through the foramen magnum, causing compression of the lower brainstem and upper cervical spinal cord. Decerebrate posturing is not observed with this lesion. The most common signs include intractable headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness due to tonsillar impaction.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation:
Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or opening in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain radiating to the back. He was diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection and proceeded to the operating room for emergent open repair. Following the procedure, the patient is brought to the post-operative care unit for further monitoring. During the patient’s postoperative assessment, he reports thoracic back pain and an inability to move the bilateral lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 98.6.0 °C (37 C °F), pulse is 30/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 195/95 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air.  Pinprick testing demonstrates bilateral loss of pain sensation below the xiphoid process. The patient has preserved proprioception, vibratory sense, fine touch, and two-point discrimination. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery
Ischemia of the posterior spinal arteries
Acute inflammation of gray and white matter spinal cord tracts
Expansion of a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient who underwent surgery for repair of an aortic dissection is found to have several neurologic deficits postoperatively. Given his findings, there is a concern for damage to the corticospinal tracts and anterior spinothalamic tracts reflective of ischemia to the anterior spinal artery.    

The spinal cord receives its blood supply through three primary arteries–one anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries. The anterior spinal artery provides blood to the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, which houses the lateral corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. The posterior spinal arteries provide blood supply to the posterior one-third of the spinal cord, which houses the dorsal column pathways.  

Ischemia to the spinal cord is an overall rare event but can occur in the setting of trauma, surgery, infection, embolic events, vasculitis, or malignancy. Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery most commonly occurs after aortic surgery–typically due to prolonged cross-clamping of the aorta. The most common area of ischemia is at the level of the Artery of Adamkiewicz, or T8. Clinically, this manifests after surgery with findings of acute back pain at the level of injury, bilateral flaccid paralysis, and loss of pain and temperature sensation, preserving the dorsal column pathway functions. Additional findings include autonomic dysfunction, respiratory failure, and spinal shock with higher thoracic and cervical lesions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ischemia of the posterior spinal arteries  :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior spinal arteries would result in diminished proprioception, vibratory sense, fine touch, and two-point discrimination as these arteries supply the dorsal column pathways.  
❌ Acute inflammation of gray and white matter spinal cord tracts :
Incorrect: Transverse myelitis does not typically occur in the setting of trauma or recent surgery but rather as a post-infectious or progressive autoimmune syndrome.  
❌ Expansion of a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord  :
Incorrect: A syrinx may present with bilateral loss of temperature and pain sensation due to the anterior white commissure disruption. It does not typically involve the lateral corticospinal tract, and therefore, motor function is preserved.  
❌ Anterior thoracic epidural hematoma:
Incorrect: Spinal epidural hematomas rarely occur outside the setting of trauma or fracture to the vertebral bodies. This patient’s presentation is instead concerning for ischemia to the anterior spinal artery.

questions.text: A 9-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of somnolence. The parent states that he left the infant sleeping on the couch, but after stepping away for a few minutes to make lunch, he found his baby on the floor next to the couch. Since then, the infant has been sleepy. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the infant appears lethargic and difficult to arouse. The anterior fontanelle is full and without associated bruising on the scalp. Ocular examination demonstrates bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant has evidence of severe intracranial trauma as evidenced by bilateral retinal hemorrhages. In addition, the proposed mechanism of injury is inconsistent with the infant’s development stage; infants are not able to roll over until at least four months of age, and therefore, this 9-week-old infant does not yet have the motor control to roll off the couch as the parent suggested. Thus there remains substantial concern for underlying child abuse.

Abusive head trauma (previously called "shaken baby syndrome") refers to cranial, cerebral or spinal injuries caused by blunt forces, shaking, or a combination of both. The classic injury pattern includes unilateral/bilateral subdural hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhages, and diffuse axonal injury with or without additional extracranial injuries.

Retinal hemorrhages are highly suggestive of child abuse; however, they can occur in other conditions. Other signs that should raise suspicion for child abuse include posterior rib fractures, unusual bruises (e.g., loop mark, bite mark, handprints), bruises in various stages of healing, cigarette burns, and injuries to the genitalia. Additionally, it is important to recognize when the proposed mechanism of injury is inconsistent with the developmental stage of the child, as in this case.

It is important for the clinician to look for and recognize these red flags, as physicians are mandated reporters to social services in all cases of suspected child abuse. If concern arises, a full skeletal survey should be performed, and child protective services should be contacted immediately.  




Option Analysis

❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis can present with lethargy and sleepiness; however, patients are typically febrile.  
❌ Vitamin K deficiency bleeding:
Incorrect: Vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB), previously known as hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, results from a newborn's inability to efficiently utilize vitamin K. Infants have low vitamin K stores due to a sterile gut, low placental transfer, and low content in breast milk. VKDB presents with cutaneous bruising, mucosal bleeding, GI bleeding, bleeding from the umbilicus, and/or intracranial hemorrhage. However, this condition rarely occurs outside the first one to two weeks of life.  
❌ Accidental trauma:
Incorrect: Accidental trauma can cause subdural hemorrhage, but this injury pattern is unlikely after a fall from couch height. The paucity of external bruising suggests a different mechanism. In addition, this proposed mechanism of injury is inconsistent with the infant’s development stage; infants are not able to roll over until at least four months of age, and therefore this 9-week-old infant does not yet have the motor control to roll off the couch as the parent suggested.  
✅ Non-accidental trauma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteogenesis imperfecta:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic bone disorder marked by brittle bones secondary to reduced production of type 1 collagen. Manifestations include fractures from low intensity trauma (e.g. birth), bone deformities, blue sclera, conductive hearing loss, and tooth abnormalities.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle crash in which he was the restrained driver and crashed into a standing car. In the ambulance, the patient is obtunded with a Glasgow scale of 4. Upon arrival at the emergency department, he is immediately intubated and taken for trauma CTs, which demonstrate multiple lesions at the gray-white junction. Vital signs are within normal limits. One day later, the patient remains in a coma and without a change in Glasgow scale, despite ventilator and sedation weaning strategies. Which of the following best explains this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.solution:
This patient most likely suffered a diffuse axonal injury (DAI) due to shearing of white matter tracts–a common and devastating form of traumatic brain injury. Patients with DAI often present in a deep coma without elevated intracranial pressure. DAI occurs as a result of traumatic shearing forces applied to the brain when the head is rapidly accelerated and/or decelerated. This injury typically affects the gray-white junction, but more severe injuries may involve the corpus callosum and/or midbrain. On imaging, multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction are typical. MRI is more sensitive than CT for detecting DAI.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cerebral hypoperfusion:
Incorrect: Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is observed in conditions such as cardiac arrest, hypovolemic shock, poisoning, or head trauma. This condition typically affects cerebral watershed areas found between cerebral vascular territories. These territories include the junction between anterior and middle cerebral arteries, as well as the posterior and middle cerebral arteries. However, this patient’s presentation and imaging findings are more consistent with diffuse axonal injury.  
❌ Rupture of bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas. CT findings of subdural hematomas show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines. In contrast, this patient’s presentation and imaging findings are more consistent with diffuse axonal injury.  
❌ Rupture of the middle meningeal artery:
Incorrect: Epidural hematoma is most commonly due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery from trauma to the pterion. Patients present with a “lucid interval” followed by rapid deterioration and death if left untreated. On a non-contrast head CT, a lens-shaped collection is typical. In contrast, this patient’s presentation and imaging findings are more consistent with diffuse axonal injury.  
✅ Shearing of white matter tracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurotransmitter-mediated excitotoxicity  :
Incorrect: Neurotransmitter-mediated excitotoxicity is a type of secondary brain injury where injured neurons release excessive glutamate, leading to overactivation injury in adjacent cells. This phenomenon is responsible for the worsening of cerebral edema, increased intracranial pressure, and clinical exacerbation of an initial brain injury. However, the CT findings in this case are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of head trauma following a bar fight. During the incident, he was struck over the side of the head with a chair and subsequently lost  consciousness for a few minutes. A few hours later, he began vomiting and experienced a severe headache. Upon arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient responds to painful stimuli only. There is left sided temporal bruising. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis. Examination of the eyes demonstrates a dilated, fixed left pupil in a down and out position. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of herniation resulting in this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient who suffered severe head trauma to the lateral side of the head presents with a fixed pupil in one eye with a down-and-out position and contralateral hemiparesis–consistent with uncal herniation.

Brain herniation occurs when cerebral tissue moves either outside of the skull or across or into a structure within the skull. Herniation is the end result of a mass effect and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) subsequent to traumatic brain injury, intracranial hemorrhage, brain tumor or abscess. When intracranial pressure increases past a defined threshold, the brain can deviate across rigid structures such as the foramen magnum, falx cerebri, and the tentorium cerebelli–resulting in predictable neurologic findings. In general, herniation syndromes are divided into those that occur above the tentorial notch (supratentorial) and those that occur below this structure (infratentorial).

In uncal herniation, the innermost portion of the temporal lobe known as the uncus compresses the tentorium. This effect compresses the 3rd cranial nerve, the cerebral peduncles, and the posterior cerebral arteries, resulting in oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and occipital lobe infarction, respectively.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Uncal herniation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Central transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Central transtentorial herniation refers to downward displacement of the diencephalon and temporal lobes through the tentorium cerebelli. This process may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Central herniation may also manifest in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries), in a complication known as a Duret hemorrhages (which is often fatal).  
❌ Subfalcine herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation refers to the lateral displacement of the innermost part of the frontal lobe (the cingulate gyrus) under the falx cerebri. This displacement can compress the anterior cerebral artery and infarct the frontal and parietal lobes. Clinical features of cingulate herniation may include unilateral/bilateral weakness, loss of bladder control, and coma.  
❌ Tonsillar herniation:
Incorrect: Tonsillar herniation, also called downward cerebellar herniation, refers to downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Clinical manifestations may include neck stiffness, flaccid paralysis, decreased level of consciousness, and signs of brain stem dysfunction from compression of respiratory and cardiac control centers.  
❌ External herniation:
Incorrect: External herniation, also known as transcalvarial herniation, refers to herniation of the brain parenchyma through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. The signs and symptoms depend upon the location and size of the herniation. This patient, however, has an intact skull.

questions.text: A 78-year-old individual presents to the neurologist for follow-up evaluation after suffering a subdural hemorrhage following a fall. The patient was recently released from inpatient rehabilitation after a long course in the hospital following hematoma evacuation. The patient’s daughter reports that the patient has regained a lot of the strength on the right side but still isn’t as “sharp” as they used to be. The patient’s daughter reports that the patient was wandering around the neighborhood yesterday and couldn’t remember where they lived. The patient’s other medical history includes diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Vitals are within normal limits. Mental status examination demonstrates the patient is only oriented to self and does not recall the time, date, or current season. When asked which family member is in the clinic with the patient, the patient is unable to provide an answer. At the beginning of the clinic visit, the patient was asked to remember the words “apple, tree, and pen,” which the patient is able to recall at the end of the visit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of memory disturbance following a traumatic brain injury. Based on their mental status examination, the patient has an inability to recall old memories while retaining the ability to form new memories – a presentation consistent with retrograde amnesia.   

Both retrograde and anterograde amnesia can result from insult to the central nervous system. Common etiologies include Alzheimer disease, traumatic brain injury, CNS infection, stroke, or malignancy. Ultimately, these disease states may result in damage to the mammillary bodies (occurs in both retrograde and anterograde amnesia) or the hippocampus (occurs in anterograde amnesia).  

If the patient develops the inability to form new memories after an insult, the condition is termed anterograde amnesia. Typically, these new memories are only held for a short period of time (hour to hour). In contrast, patients with retrograde amnesia develop an inability to recall old memories following an insult, including people, events, and personal information.

Option Analysis

✅ Retrograde amnesia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Anterograde amnesia :
Incorrect: Anterograde reflects an inability to form new memories following a pathological CNS insult. The above vignette demonstrates evidence of retrograde amnesia.  
❌ Transient global amnesia:
Incorrect: Transient global amnesia refers to a type of anterograde amnesia. Unlike typical anterograde amnesia, this condition results in an acute “broken record” phenomenon, where patients suddenly do not form new memories. The condition is a benign, self-limited condition. 
❌ Dissociative amnesia :
Incorrect: Dissociative amnesia refers to a person’s inability to recall important personal information, typically following severe emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Delirium:
Incorrect: Delirium refers to acute, fluctuating changes in sensorium, typically secondary to an underlying illness.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a sudden onset severe headache. An hour ago, the patient woke up suddenly with an excruciating headache that reached maximum intensity within seconds. His additional medical history includes hypertension and a 20 pack year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. On physical examination, nuchal rigidity is noted. A non-contrast CT of the head is obtained and is unremarkable. A lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient’s cerebrospinal fluid?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a sudden onset of headache and neck stiffness, raising concerns for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), for which he has significant risk factors (e.g. hypertension and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which is associated with arteriovenous malformations). When a clinical presentation is highly suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and the initial CT-brain is negative, the next best step is to obtain a lumbar puncture, which may demonstrate blood or xanthochromia.

A lumbar puncture is performed by inserting a spinal needle between the 4th-5th lumbar intervertebral space to evaluate for frank blood or metabolized blood products in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Once blood products become metabolized, CSF appears a straw-yellow color, termed xanthochromia. In addition, cerebrospinal fluid analysis is performed to examine for the persistence of red blood cells in tubes one through four. An increasing, or persistently high, titer of red blood cells suggests underlying SAH. Importantly, this procedure should not be performed if a patient has an underlying coagulopathy, severe thrombocytopenia, or overlying infectious process near the puncture site. In addition, patients should not have this procedure performed if they have established evidence of elevated intracranial pressure, as lumbar puncture may precipitate cerebral herniation. For this reason, a CT-brain is indicated prior to performing the lumbar puncture.

Once the diagnosis of SAH has been established, localization of the bleeding using digital subtraction angiography (DSA), computed tomography angiography (CTA), or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is indicated prior to treatment (surgical clipping or coiling).  



Option Analysis

✅ Xanthochromia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Low glucose:
Incorrect: A low cerebrospinal fluid glucose level is often detected in cases of bacterial meningitis, not subarachnoid hemorrhage.  
❌ High neutrophil count:
Incorrect: A high neutrophil count in cerebrospinal fluid is more often associated with bacterial meningitis, not subarachnoid hemorrhage.  
❌ High lymphocyte count  :
Incorrect: A high lymphocyte count is more commonly associated with viral or aseptic meningitis, not subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the back. On primary survey, his Glasgow coma score is 15 with his airway, breathing, and circulation intact. Secondary survey is notable for a stab wound to the midline of his lumbar spine at the L1 level. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 11/min, blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Neurologic examination is notable for ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception below the L1 level, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning approximately at the L3-L4 level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception below the level of injury along with contralateral loss of temperature and pain sensation after sustaining a stab wound to the spine. His findings are consistent with Brown-Sequard syndrome, which refers to hemi-section of the spinal cord.    

Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare spinal cord injury pattern that occurs following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or less commonly fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception due to damage of the dorsal columns and corticospinal tract. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to damage of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure). Furthermore, Brown-Sequard syndrome may be associated with Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) if the lesion occurs above the T1 level and causes damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.

   

Option Analysis

✅  Brown-Sequard syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Central cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome commonly occurs due to forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities. Stab wounds, as in the case of this patient, would not usually cause central cord syndrome.  
❌ Anterior cord syndrome :
Incorrect: Anterior cord syndrome typically results from anterior spinal artery occlusion, which leads to bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the lesion. It would not manifest with ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception combined with contralateral loss of temperature and pain sensation. 
❌ Cauda equina syndrome :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia.  
❌ Complete cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Complete cord syndrome refers to complete transection of the spinal cord, of which the most common etiology is trauma. Patients with complete transection of the spinal cord will present with signs of neurogenic shock including decreased systemic vascular resistance and increased vagal tone, which result in hypotension with paradoxical bradycardia. Additionally, patients will have complete loss of motor function, sensation, and proprioception below the level of the injury.
